newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss stocks end at record highs.
newsitem.headline: Swiss stocks end at record highs.

text.p: Swiss shares again ended at a record closing highs on Friday as the dollar's gains propelled stocks to new peaks, dealers said.
The broad Swiss Performance Index (SPI) ended up 10.31 points at record high of 2,579.26.

The blue-chip Swiss Market Index (SMI) was up 12.8 at a record close of 4,019.9, just below its intra-day all-time high of 4,022.4. Dealers said the market expected analysts to raise their profit forecast for Swiss companies generally due to the dollar's gains versus the Swiss franc.
Dollar earners like Nestle and Holderbank were higher. Watchmaker SMH rose strongly.
Demand focused on industrials, which tend to benefit from a stronger dollar, while financial stocks were largely neglected.
Trade was seen as nervous on strong volume, traders said.
Expiry of futures and options on the Swiss Soffex exchange also supported cash prices.
Among pharmaceuticals, Roche was up 65 Swiss francs at 11,050, leading the actives list. The share was supported by new buy recommendations.
Novartis closed steady at 1,548 with dealers saying some investors swapped Novartis for Roche.
Banks were mixed. Union Bank of Switzerland fell six Swiss francs to 1,149, partially on technical factors. The bank was also downgraded by Standard & Poor's on Thursday.
Credit Suisse Group rose 2.50 to 140.25 on buy recommendations. Dealers also said CS Group's new CEO Lukas Muehlemann held a roadshow which was favourably received.
Swiss Bank Corp added 0.75 francs to 249.75.
Insurers were lower, with Swiss Re seven francs lower at 1,391.
Winterthur lost eight to 779 after Moody's said on Thursday it had lowered its rating for the insurer.
